reviewText: Donna Summer is a musical legend who has transcended trends and whose career has outlasted many of her contempories. This is a short dvd compilation of some of her 'arguably' better videos from the 80's, but its so sad that an artist of her stature has yet to receive the full dvd career retrospective treatment encompassing her groundbreaking 70's work (yes there are clips availble) ALL her 80's and 90's music videos and more. In 1994 a vhs collection of videos (also incomplete) entitled Endless Summer was released and at least it was a half hearted attempt to capture some of her video work on one collection. This is only for the non fans who want a cheap collection of 5 videos.
Title: N/A

reviewText: PRO- The sound quality is good.CONS- Most of the video scenes look washed out.- There's no SUBTITLES. Consequently, I can't sing along. This is the thing I hate the most.- There are only 5 songs on DVD. They are "Yellow Moon", "Bird on a Wire", "Sister Rosa", "Fearless" and "Fly Like an Eagle"It's worth buying of you're a fan of the Neville Brothers. I bought it because of "Bird on a Wire" song. I love the song after watching the movie with the same title starring Mel Gibson.
summary: Washed out video + Containing only 5 songs + NO SUBTITLES

reviewText: Videos by Tears for fears are great. This DVD is OK for people who like a bit of TFF but who are not interested in paying more than 10 $ for a few of the great songs and videos. Forget about extras at this price. 20th Century collection is for a collector of about every kind of music without being a big fan. With this serie of DVDs, you can get a few cheap priced DVDs with a short, but good content.Unfortunatly, videos on this DVD are not the best. A lot of content is missing. If you want a bit more, buy the official "Tears Roll Down" greatest hits videos. You will get twice as many videos. Sound quality is the same on both DVDs, same recording as on the CD.I gave *** because of the good value. The content is very short.
summary: Great videos, good value, but not for fans.....

reviewText: These five clips were made during Steve Earle's brief flirtation with major label success, when MCA Records thought highly enough of him to shoot some videos and send 'em out to the TV folks.  It includes one of his biggest hits, "Guitar Town," as well as "Someday," "Nowhere Road," "Copperhead Road" and "I Ain't Never Satisfied," which retells the old Robert Johnson legend, of a man who sold his soul ot the devil in order to become a guitar legend.  For the most part, these videos are pretty low-budget and by-the-numbers, but what's cool is seeing Earle as a young Nashville outsider, before he moved into his biker-ish, leather-clad outlaw persona... He's so fresh-faced and earnest... and so young!  Fans will want to watch him back then, to remember when he was bright-eyed and idealistic... This is a modest video package, but the material is really nice.
summary: Steve Earle when he was fresh-faced and young
Title: N/A

reviewText: I guess this is for the real casual Tears For Fears fan.  None of the videos from their album "The Hurting" are here at all.  You get the major singles from "Songs From The Big Chair," and one video from their 1989 album.  It's very unsatisfying if you have seen all of their videos.  I for one think the videos for "Change" and "Pale Shelter" are awesome.  So if you just casually want to watch a few TFF videos and relive the 80's this might be for you but if you are a die hard fan you might be disapointed.

reviewText: This may be short, but it sure is great in my opinion, and well worth the price. The songs are great, the filming, the sound, everything is fantastic. It's well worth the purchase price, just for the video of "Sister Rosa" alone. In this video, they re-inact, the story of the legendary, civil rights heroin, Rosa Parks, and how she refused to give up her bus seat, to a white man, in Montgomery, Alabama, back during segregation. It shows how her refusal to give up her bus seat, lead to the Civil Rights movement, and how Dr.King took up her cause. It's a great video story, very well portrayed. Also, I really like "Fly Like an Eagle", this is the old Steve Miller song, and is performed very well by the Neville Brothers. I like this dvd, very much, and I gladly recommend it.
summary: This may be short, but is simply outstanding. It's worth the cost just for the Video of "Sister Rosa". Definitely Worth the Buy!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Once again, labels assume fans wil rush out and buy anything sub-par just because it's on DVD format - yes, it's nice to have a mere FIVE videos on DVD for posterity, but these are clearly my least favorite of Donna's videos/hits - where are here videos/live/TV performances from here "Bad Girls" era?  Instead of releasing these to cash-in on Donna's popularity, why not do a deal with ABC and release her amazing, long lost 1979 one-hour TV special she did featuring live versions of "Dim All the Lights," a special promo of "Bad Girls/Hot Stuff," "Sunset People" and more!  I remember as a kid begging my parents to let me stay up late so I could watch - and once I did, I was TRANSFIXED by Donna's beauty and sheer vocal talent!  If you look at other "best of" DVDs out there (like BOWIE's, THE JAM, THE CLASH, etc.) that feature stuff from the vaults, the LACK of old 70s clips is pointless to purchase for true fans - heck, even the more recent MELODY OF LOVE from "Endless Summer" VHS isn't here, WHY?!!  Donna did a slew of early TV appearances singing her old disco hits LIVE - where are THOSE?  Until then, I refuse to buy these cheap, exploitive DVDs!
summary: Why not release Donna's ABC 70s TV special on DVD? PLEASE!

reviewText: I saw Robert one week ago today, opening for Sir Eric Clapton. I own several of his CDs and this DVD. At the concert, people were talking and waiting for Clapton for the first couple of songs. Before his set was over, all were in to his fabulous vocals and guitar licks. He got two standing ovations before he finished and the crowd shouted out for more.To end the evening, Clapton brought Robert out to close the show, singing the Robert Johnson tune (and a Clapton signature song) Crossroads.No doubt, the folks who weren't aware of Mr. Cray's work were shopping for his recordings all this week.
summary: Pure Blues---All MTV or VHS Videos

reviewText: This is one of a series of no-frills five-clip video collections issued by various classic pop artists.  Accordingly, you get what you paid for, nothing more (e.g., there is a menu on the DVD but no surround sound).  On this DVD what you get are five videos from Donna's intermittent 1980s "comebacks" into the pop mainstream, including SHE WORKS HARD FOR THE MONEY, THIS TIME I KNOW IT'S FOR REAL, and three others covering 1983-89.  The clips are standard MTV/VH1 period pieces, with content appropriate for viewers of all ages.  In my opinion, the music is more dynamic than the clips for the most part.Keep in mind that Donna's 1975-1979 days as a pop/disco superstar came prior to the videoclip era, so any clip collection -- including a more comprehensive one issued a few years ago -- is not going to have her hits from the most memorable period of her career.  I once owned that previous set on laserdisc, and recall that there are roughly enough post-1979 videoclips to fill a second volume of this size.  Beyond that there's not much else available clip-wise that I'm aware of. Anyway, here's an economical place to get five of them.  Fans will want more, but probably the label didn't feel a full-length, full-price collection would have much of a market.
summary: A good bargain for the price (collectors will want more)

reviewText: I'm sick of people complaining about the "lack" of videos for these 80's compilations. You're getting what your paying for, 8 bucks for 5 great videos. I've seen CD's with 5 tracks on it for about that same price before and this a quality DVD. These five videos are their best known songs, if you want more, you won't get it because they didn't make anymore videos. Head Over Heals, Sowing the Seeds Of Love, Shout, Everybody Wants To Rule the World and one lesser known. The videos themselves are great and a must have for fans. Sowing the Seeds of Love is one of the most underrated songs ever and still kickin' today in 2004. I will want my Dolby Digital 5.1 for these, but I can't have everything I want. Either way, 5 great videos for 8 bucks, it's a good deal if you love the 80's and appreciate great 80's vintage especially Tears for Fears. The music coming out now can't compare to what these guys did, this is just music really worth listening too. Sit back and rehash the 80's! Get them all!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This budget priced, nicely packaged little DVD collection of five Olivia Newton-John music video clips is a great little gem for the Livvy fan! Songs are from Livvy's "rock" stage, pulling cuts from the 1979-1982 era. So in these clips, Olivia truly rocks a bit! It includes footage rarely seen in 3 of the clips, and one can only imagine how many jaw's dropped as Olivia danced on the rooftop in the final track, surrounding NY's trendy manhatten area.I won't complain about the fact there are only five songs, as the great low retail price and quality is excellent, along with some rare footage.But I hope more Olivia Newton-John DVD's are issued, especially her famous "Physical" video music album, previously available on VHS.

reviewText: This 5 song dvd is must have despite the fact that it is only 17 minutes long. Four of the videos not including Physical are hard to find and have rarely been seen since their premeir back in the late 70's and early 80's. The sound quality is amazing and what impressed me most about it is the fact that it has given these songs a freshness not heard even on the rematers of the cd's Totally Hot and Physical. The picture quality is also one of the best I have seen. The only downside is the shortness of the dvd considering Olivia has done so many videos over the years. One can only hope they all see the light of day on dvd, along with her 1982 concert from Utah.

reviewText: Dennis DeYoung became a reluctant solo artist in 1984, after the break-up of his band, Styx.These videos reflect songs from his three solo albums from the 1980's.  Besides having a stellar, one-of-a-kind voice, Dennis proved he was very ready for his close-up on video.The standout is "Desert Moon", which was a top ten single and one of the most popular videos on MTV in 1984.  It mirrors the reflective, you-can't-go-home-again theme of the song.  And, of course, there is the famous red Mustang."Don't Wait For Heroes" has some of the trademark wacky humor of DeYoung, plus an interesting story and it is just a great song on its own."Call Me" is a moody, atmospheric set piece using the paintings of American artist Edward Hopper as inspiration for its theme of loneliness and its muted tones of red and green.  Again, a great, soulful Dennis DeYoung song."Boomchild" is a wild, effects-filled look at the whole Baby Boom generation.  It is chock full of boomer references and it is fun just to watch and pick them all out.  As clever a video as was ever on MTV/VH1.  Again, Dennis looks great, and the song is filled with themes that resonate today.  I do not think there has been a better summation of the whole boomer experience than the lyrics in this song.A standout video collection.  A must-have if you are any kind of Classic Styx fan or enjoy the work of Dennis DeYoung.

reviewText: Only five videos ... but like Alanis Morrissette named a recent album: FEAST ON SCRAPS!!This DVD brought back such good memories.  Olivia was da bomb back in the 80's.  For a few years after GREASE, she was riding high.  My sister had all her albums and I listened, too!I'm so excited to see the TOTALLY HOT video.  This song rocks!  I'm partial to anything with horns in the arrangement ... and Olivia's "dance break" in the middle of the song is fantastic.  Nobody can strut in pumps like Olivia can.  (Trivia: Are those the same black GREASE pants that she had to be sewn into??)I forgot how fun PHYSICAL was.  And the muscle dudes in speedos are ... hot.HEART ATTACK is cheesy ... but I'm not complaining.  Cheesy is fun (just rent XANADU, one of my favorites!).I'm not sure if Olivia made any more videos  --- I seem to remember a sexy vid a few years later with fire and Olivia in a bed with two muscle dudes walking toward her -- but these are a lot of fun and bring back lots of fond memories."So hot / totally hot / you got to me!"

reviewText: For Universal, they've really been quite able to capitalize on the feeling of their 20th Century masters collection so much with the CD's, but now the feel of the DVD's are quite ironic on the downside. Considering, most of them do overlook great videos, and only offer the value within the acrtual bbudget price. That has happened with so many acts like Patti LaBelle, Styx, Olivia Newton-John, and the former Miss America, Vanessa Williams. Yet for Vanessa, her music has always find a way to bring beauty and elegance to the mainstream, but for a decent collection of her music videos, that just hasn't happened here.20th Century Masters: Vanessa Williams is a DVD that only features five of her soulful music videos from her career, with a lot of beauty in her voice. The videos range mostly from her first 2 records, The Right Stuff and The Comfort Zone with videos for The Sweetest Days, the #1 ballad Save The Best For Last, Dreamin', and Runnin' Back To You. The videos are great and dynamic, but there are just too few tracks here as a far cry from the 20th Century Masters album. The DVD overshadows quite a lot of music videos includng the videos for Happiness, Colors Of The Wind, The Look from The Right Stuff, The Way That You Love, and other great songs.While Vanessa Williams fans might be a bit dissapointed in this DVD collection, it is a very decent music video collection but could've been improved quite a bit. This is a big problem for the 20th Century Masters DVD edition. Still, it is a good price for die hard Vanessa Williams fans but others may just want to buy the CD instead of the DVD. This one might want to be saved for last, until a better collection of her videos comes out.Price: C+Mastering: BVideos: C-Overall: C 1/2-

reviewText: This has been a long time coming. But alas, Hip-O Records is releasing several Olivia music videos on DVD. Olivia has been a pioneer for music video. Her 1981 television special "Physical" was revolutionary. She was the first artist to make a video album. Meaning every song on the album was made into a music video and released as an hour long prime time television event. The 1981 video collection was a huge best seller, as was the album and single of the same name.Here in this DVD collection, we get the obligatory video of "Physical". Also included are video tracks from her earlier smash hit album "Totally Hot". The videos from the 1978 album are very rare and make this DVD worth the purchase. You must see Olivia in these videos still riding high from her GREASE success and looking simply beautiful.I must say this is a wonderful collection even if it is only 5 songs. Hopefully there will be more Olivia video releases to follow.The Tracks are as follows:PhysicalHeart AttackDeeper Than The NightTotally HotA Little More Love
summary: At Last, The Gorgeous Olivia Newton-John On DVD

I'll give you a list of all Commodores videos that I know of that had the original lineup thats is missing from this set: 1)Brick House 2)Sail On 3)Still 4)Lady (You Bring Me Up) 5)Oh No.  There was a video for "Reach High" that was also excluded from the dvd that was recorded and released after Lionel Richie left the Commodores!  There was no excuse for this poorly constructed, lazy excuse for a Commodores dvd compilation.

reviewText: This compilation may only have five videos and is very short, but if you're a Donna Summer fan like me, you will undoubtedly enjoy this budget-priced compilation.What is very striking about this compilation is how well Donna made the transition from disco/radio phenomenon to video star.  Many stars in the '70s had to adjust to becoming video stars, and some made that transition better than others.It helps, of course, that Donna is a beautiful woman, but her ability to emote well for the camera suggests that she should  perhaps pursue more acting.  She's strong and independent in "She Works Hard For the Money"; makes a striking transition from frumpty headmaster into sexy teacher in "Unconditional Love" and convincingly plays a war bride in "There Goes My Baby".As a reviewer remarked earlier, "This Time I Know It's For Real" and "Love's About To Change My Heart" really show Donna in a fresh light.  She looks stunning in these videos, playing up the "dance goddess" image without being sleazy or made-up.  She looks the most relaxed ever at this point in her career, even dancing freely for the camera, and sadly after this point, Donna would pretty much make sporadic public and chart appearances.It's a great little video to play at parties or if you just want to see Donna in her '80s heyday.
